title: Quantum scars in many-body systems
authors: Andrea Pizzi, Bertrand Evrard, Ceren B. Dag, and Johannes Knolle
abstract:
Chaos makes isolated systems of many interacting particles quickly thermalize
and forget about their past. Here, we show that quantum mechanics hinders chaos
in many-body systems: although the quantum eigenstates are thermal and strongly
entangled, exponentially many of them are scarred, that is, have an enlarged
weight along underlying classical unstable periodic orbits. Scarring makes the
system more likely to be found on an orbit it was initialized on, retaining a
memory of its past and thus weakly breaking ergodicity, even at long times and
despite the system being fully thermal. We demonstrate the ubiquity of quantum
scarring in many-body systems by considering a large family of spin models,
including some of the most popular ones from condensed matter physics. Our
findings, at hand for modern quantum simulators, prove structure in spite of
chaos in many-body quantum systems.
